articles.title: Farmers and landowners urged to burn land responsibly
articles.author: Meg Jenkins
articles.summary: The appeal comes from the Wales Wildfire Board as part of its #BurnToProtect campaign to reduce the risk of wildfires during the designated burn season, which runs from October 1 to March 15 or until March 31 in upland areas. A Burn Plan is required to ensure safe burning of heather, grass, bracken, and gorse. There have been 3,289 wildfires in Wales since January 2025.

articles.title: Families with sick children, in complete poverty following rains in Santiago de Cuba
articles.author: Ciber Cuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: Heavy rains in recent days left families with sick children in extreme poverty and housing vulnerability in several neighborhoods of the eastern capital. There are partial collapses and homes on the verge of collapse. The situation compromises the safety of children, the sick, and the elderly. Two men, aged 53 and 60, died after the collapse of their homes, while two people remain missing.

articles.title: Expert points to erosion as houses collapse in Outer Banks, says there is no clear solution

articles.summary: Houses are collapsing in Outer Banks due to erosion. University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill professor Laura Moore says there is no clear solution to the problem. More frequent and severe storms are intensifying coastal erosion, she says.      Â

articles.author: Rachel Duensing
articles.summary: Huge waves from hurricanes Imelda and Humberto caused houses to fall into the ocean in Buxton, N.C. According to the Cape Hatteras National Seashore, 18 structures have collapsed into the sea since 2020. By 2050, a coastal flood of 3 feet is expected every year for Dare County in North Carolina.

Many people suggest spending money on beach renourishment.

articles.summary: 'We need to do what we can sensibly to tackle climate change but we cannot do it alone. If other countries aren't doing it, then us being the goody-two-shoes of the world is not encouraging anyone to improve,' Mrs Badenoch said.

articles.title: There is a high chance of a La Niña event in the fall, and a medium chance for the winter, so what could this bring for South Carolina?
articles.author: Irene Sans
articles.summary: The El Niño-Southern Oscillation, also known as ENSO, is a phenomenon that occurs in the tropical Pacific Ocean. La Niña events typically occur every 3 to 5 years, but the interval between events can vary from 2 to 7 years. This fall, there is a 71% chance of LaNiña developing and persisting through December. There is a 54% chance between December and February during winter months. Long-term models continue to indicate a decrease through the spring of 2026.

articles.title: Deep-sea sediment cores reveal major ecological turnover before warming event 56 million years ago
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: A large proportion of the carbon dioxide emissions that are currently being released into the atmosphere by human activities are absorbed by the surface ocean, which makes it more CO2-rich for the atmosphere and sea surface.   Â. Â   y

articles.summary: Six houses on North Carolina's Outer Banks collapsed into the ocean Tuesday as two hurricanes churned up heavy surf. Since 2020, 18 private homes have fallen into the Atlantic Ocean, as rising sea levels climb over the beaches. The collapses have become a symbol of climate change.

articles.title: September 2025 weather in Chilliwack was second-warmest on record
articles.author: Jennifer Feinberg
articles.summary: September 2025 was the second warmest on record in Chilliwack. It was the fourth consecutive September with below-normal rainfall. The local Coastal Fire Centre Category 1 campfire ban and fire prohibitions were in effect from July 17 to Sept. 25. The precipitation total to date for 2025 is 679.9 mm (41.4 per cent below normal) on 96 days compared to the 30-year average of 1,160.5 mm on 117 days.

articles.title: September was hottest on record in Okinawa
articles.summary: The temperature in Okinawa in September was the highest since statistics began in 1946. More than 100,000 people were taken to hospital with heatstroke this summer.

articles.author: Newser Editors
articles.summary: Six unoccupied houses along North Carolina's Outer Banks have collapsed into the ocean as hurricanes Humberto and Imelda rumble in the Atlantic. Five of the houses collapsed on Tuesday afternoon in Buxton, a community on the string of islands that make up the Outer Banks. A sixth one collapsed overnight. No injuries have been reported.

articles.summary: Switzerland's glaciers have experienced a significant melt, losing 3% of their total ice mass over the last year. In the realm of genetic science, researchers have made strides in reproducing human eggs using skin cells. Preliminary lab results indicate a potential breakthrough for women facing challenges with dysfunctional natural eggs.

articles.title: The Urgency of New Jersey Passing the Climate Superfund Act
articles.author: Mikayla Vigilanti
articles.summary: Mikayla Vigilanti is calling for New Jersey Legislation to pass the Climate Superfund Act. This Act requires fossil-fueled companies to pay for state programming that funds climate recovery and other similar projects. Over 50 municipalities in New Jersey have already passed a resolution in support of the bill.

articles.title: Agriculture One Of Most Vulnerable Sectors To Climate Change, Mukhtar Babayev Says

articles.title: North Carolina homes collapse as dual hurricanes bring strong winds, waves
articles.author: Josephine Walker
articles.summary: At least 18 privately-owned homes have collapsed along North Carolina's Outer Banks since 2020 due to rising seas and storms. The erosion is also contributing to the loss of habitats for shorebirds and sea turtles along the Cape Hatteras National Seashore. Imelda will bring hurricane-force winds to Bermuda on Wednesday evening.

articles.title: Climate Change Alters Ocean Stratification Dynamics
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: There has been a marked increase in ocean stratification over the last 60 years. The most drastic changes are evident in tropical regions, where rising temperatures have driven the increase. Stratification plays a crucial role in the ocean's capacity to exchange heat, carbon dioxide, oxygen, and nutrients. As the ocean becomes warmer and more stratified, deeper waters tend to hold more nutrients, which can affect the productivity of marine ecosystems.

articles.title: Coastal areas brace for strong winds as low pressure intensifies into depression
articles.author: Sports Correspondent
articles.summary: The low-pressure system in the western-central Bay of Bengal has advanced north-northwest and intensified into a depression. The Bangladesh Meteorological Department issued a special bulletin on Wednesday afternoon warning the Chattogram, Cox's Bazar, Mongla, and Payra sea ports to display cautionary signal No. 3.

articles.title: The oceans keep score in a year of record heat around Australia
articles.summary: In the past year, Australia's oceans have been hotter than ever before. The east coast was battered by severe flooding, and off the west coast the simmering seas caused widespread coral bleaching. Warmer oceans allow for more water to evaporate, increasing moisture in the atmosphere, which fuels rain clouds.

articles.title: Analysis: Obama's anti-human ‘climate change' panic almost destroyed USA, still targets children
articles.author: Editor Two

Obama targeted children in their formative years with climate terror.

articles.title: Gov't helping hinterland farmers manage water challenges better
articles.author: Editor
articles.summary: Guyana has been experiencing longer dry seasons due to changing weather patterns and the effects of El Niño. The Agriculture Ministry has been proactive in putting systems in place to prevent drought-like problems for farmers in hinterland communities. It has built water catchment ponds and expanded drainage and irrigation works and invested in new pump stations to support farmers.

articles.title: Home collapses in the Outer Banks as hurricanes swirl offshore

articles.summary: Six unoccupied houses along North Carolina's Outer Banks have collapsed into the ocean as Hurricanes Humberto and Imelda rumble in the Atlantic. These are among the latest private beachfront structures to fall as sea levels rise due to global warming.

articles.title: Six more houses collapsed into the sea in the Outer Banks
articles.summary: Six unoccupied houses along North Carolina's Outer Banks have collapsed into the ocean as Hurricanes Humberto and Imelda rumble in the Atlantic. The houses are the latest private beachfront structures to fall as sea levels rise due to global warming. The next one is due to fall on October 1, 2025.

articles.title: As California glaciers disappear, people will see ice-free peaks exposed for the first time in millennia
articles.author: Ian James
articles.summary: Glaciers in the Sierra Nevada have probably existed since the last Ice Age more than 11,000 years ago. The remnants of these glaciers have shrunk dramatically since the late 1800s and are retreating. They are projected to melt completely this century as global temperatures continue to rise. A future glacier-free Sierra Nevada is unprecedented in human history.

articles.title: Omitting emissions
articles.author: Mark Lawson
articles.summary: The federal government wants to reduce national emissions by 62 to 70 per cent on 2005 levels by 2035. Australia's contribution to global emissions is 1.3 per cent. China, the USA and India are the world's largest emitters of CO2. They are not paying much attention to the Paris Agreement. Agricultural production has increased by 34 per cent over the past 20 years.

articles.title: Bering Land Bridge emerged much later than we thought it did, new study finds
articles.author: Charles Q. Choi
articles.summary: The Bering Land Bridge that once connected Asia and Alaska may have emerged much later during the last ice age than previously thought. The land bridge existed about 35,000 years ago, before the coldest part of the last glacial maximum (LGM). This jibes with one of the oldest reputably dated sites of human activity in the Americas — the 23,000-year-old footprints found at White Sands National Park in New Mexico.

articles.title: PDMA warns of heavy rains, more floods in Punjab next week
articles.author: News Desk
articles.summary: A tropical depression is forming over the northeast Arabian Sea and is expected to bring heavy rains to Sindh this week. A westerly system is forecast to unleash heavy downpours across Punjab early next week. Since the onset of rains on June 26, over 1,000 people have died across the country and more than 4.7 million have been affected in Punjab.

articles.title: Reform route flagged as best road to economic recovery
articles.author: Jacob Shteyman
articles.summary: The report urges the government to turn its recent economic roundtable into an annual fixture. The report warns that the green shoots in Australia's economy could wither without further reform, if the government does not do more to reform the economy.   .

articles.title: How you can effectively take personal action to reduce your carbon footprint and combat climate change. Subby submitted this headline so he should be good for the rest of the week at least (bbc.com) 32
articles.summary: Quitting your job in AI, marketing, travel, and any sort of selling is more important than changing behavior in the first place. Corporations are working for YOU and most of you all have benefited from their largesse just fine. It's time to grow up.

articles.title: Heat records broken in a dozen Manitoba communities
articles.author: Kayla Rosen
articles.summary: Southerly winds brought unseasonably warm weather across Manitoba on Tuesday. Berens River reached a new high of 25.9 C, beating its previous record of 23.3 C set in 1931. Winnipeg and Pilot Mound both reached temperatures above 30 C, surpassing heat records set in 1989 and 1963. Swan River and Carberry experienced record-breaking temperatures above 31 C. Fisher Branch and Oak Point beat 55-year-old heat records. Norway House bested its record from just four years ago. Pinawa, Pine Falls, Shoal Lake and Steinbach also logged record-setting heat on Tuesday, with all four communities reaching temperatures above 27 C.

articles.title: Beachfront houses collapsed into the Atlantic surf along North Carolina's Outer Banks
articles.author: Gary D. Robertson
articles.summary: Six unoccupied houses along North Carolina's Outer Banks have collapsed into the ocean as Hurricanes Humberto and Imelda rumble in the Atlantic. Five of the houses collapsed on Tuesday afternoon in Buxton, a community on the string of islands that make up the Outer Banks. A sixth one collapsed overnight. Eighteen privately owned houses have now collapsed on Seashore beaches since 2020.

articles.title: New Tactics, But Climate Crusaders Running Out Of Options
articles.author: Tyler Durden
articles.summary: For the first time, scientists have found a link between worsening heat waves and global warming pollution from individual fossil fuel and cement companies. This is despite the fact that the federal government is moving away from the grip of climate change fever. Chris Wright, energy secretary in the Trump administration, has argued that renewable energy projects developed with the aim of reducing fossil fuels were not beneficial to the United States.

articles.title: Local author pens children's book inspired by sapling that survived Hurricane Helene
articles.author: nick.fogleman
articles.summary: Anna Welsh has released a new children's book inspired by a local family's experience during Hurricane Helene. Erin and Will Selle temporarily relocated closer to town and found their garden destroyed and their belongings swept away. A four-foot sapling was almost completely submerged, but it survived.

articles.title: Japan records third-hottest September in history due to ongoing heat trend
articles.author: Dimsum Daily Newsroom
articles.summary: Japan has experienced its third-warmest September since meteorological records began in 1898. The nationwide average temperature for September 2025 was 2.49 degrees Celsius above the 30-year baseline average established for the period between 1991 and 2020. The record for the hottest September was set in 2023, when temperatures soared 2.66 degrees Celsius, followed by 2024, 2.52 degrees higher.

articles.title: Minnesota turkey farmers use lasers to scare away migrating birds
articles.summary: Migrating birds are a threat to turkey farmers in Minnesota. Some farmers are using lasers to scare them away. Minnesota Public Radio's Dana Ferguson reports on this story from WBUR's Delaware Public Media website. It was originally published on WBUR.org.

articles.title: Switzerland's ice mass declined by one-quarter this decade
articles.author: Jamey Keaten
articles.summary: Switzerland's glaciers experienced an "enormous" 3% decline in volume this year. This is the fourth-largest annual decline on record. Over 1,000 small glaciers in Switzerland have already disappeared due to global warming. The ongoing glacial retreat has implications for hydropower, tourism, farming, and water resources across Europe.

articles.title: Wisconsin bird migration
articles.author: Usa Today Via Reuters Connect
articles.summary: Migration season in Wisconsin is in full swing. Millions of birds have been migrating across Wisconsin every night since late August. The largest migration surge was on Sept. 17, when more than 52 million birds migrated over Wisconsin. Migratory and hunting season for birds can start as early as August and run as late as November in Wisconsin.

articles.title: 'Can't put into words': Australian activists aboard Gaza flotilla talk about final approach
articles.author: 9News
articles.summary: The Global Sumud Flotilla consists of about 50 boats and 500 activists from 44 nations, including at least six Australians. The flotilla is carrying a symbolic amount of aid and has remained undeterred in its mission to break the Israeli blockade of the coastal strip and reach Palestinians. The ships were sailing in international waters north of Egypt on Wednesday morning and had entered a "danger zone" - which Israeli authorities had warned them not to cross. Overnight, two Israeli warships approached two of their boats, circling around them and jamming their communications, including the live cameras on board.

articles.title: Japan logs 3rd-hottest September on record
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: Japan's average temperature in September marked the third highest since records began in 1898, the weather agency said Wednesday. According to the Japan Meteorological Agency, the temperature was in the mid-teens in September. The average temperature for the whole of September was in mid-20s in Japan.

articles.title: Swiss Glaciers Face "Enormous" Melting, Shrank By A Quarter In Past Decade
articles.author: Associated Press
articles.summary: Glacier volume in Switzerland has declined by 3% this year, the fourth-largest annual drop on record due to the effects of global warming. Switzerland is home to nearly 1,400 glaciers, the most of any country in Europe. The retreat and loss of glaciers is also having an impact on Switzerland's landscape.

articles.title: Maryland's Supreme Court should leave climate policy to policymakers
articles.author: Mary D. Kane
articles.summary: Maryland's Supreme Court will consider on Oct. 6 whether cities and counties can use state civil law to pursue claims against energy producers related to global climate change. The Justice Department, 24 state attorneys general and various organizations have urged the court to dismiss the appeals.

articles.summary: There is no greenhouse gas effect. Sun irradiates earth with mostly visible light, some IR, some UV. Earth's orbit varies by about 1.667%. The amount of energy we receive varies by the inverse square of the distance. Most of the earth's surface is in the northern hemisphere. Earth releases more IR when it receives the least sunlight.

The glacier retreat has implications for hydropower, tourism, farming, and water resources across Europe, with over 1,000 small glaciers in Switzerland already having vanished.

articles.title: USDA gives $531 million for Georgia farm relief
articles.summary: The U.S. Department of Agriculture will provide more than US$531 million in recovery assistance to Georgia farmers and ranchers affected by Hurricane Helene. The funding will be distributed through a block grant agreement with the Georgia Agriculture Department. The grant agreement will cover economic losses, infrastructure damage, and timber losses.

articles.title: La Niña is likely to start very soon. Here's what that means for Texas this winter.
articles.author: Anthony Franze
articles.summary: NOAA has issued a La Niña watch for October and November. It's when sea-surface temperatures in the eastern Pacific Ocean are at least 0.5 degrees Celsius below average for three months. It is expected to form between September and November, with chances rising to 71% for the October-December period. It will be relatively weak, but there is a 26% chance that sea- surface temperatures could drop more than 1 degree Celsius below the three-month average. It can have a significant impact on the weather in Texas.

articles.title: Swiss glaciers shrank 3% this year, the fourth-biggest retreat on record, experts say
articles.author: Jamey Keaten
articles.summary: Switzerland's glaciers have faced 'enormous' melting this year with a 3% drop in total volume due to the effects of global warming. The shrinkage is the fourth-largest after those in 2022, 2023 and back in 2003. The retreat and loss of glaciers is also having an impact on Switzerland's landscape.

articles.title: Swiss glaciers shrank 3% this year, the fourth-biggest retreat on record, experts say
articles.author: Jamey Keaten
articles.summary: Swiss glaciers shrank 3% this year, the fourth-biggest retreat on record, experts say. The shrinkage means that ice mass in Switzerland has declined by one-quarter over the last decade. More than 1,000 small glaciers in Switzerland have already disappeared.

articles.title: Why hotter summers are bad for the UK economy
articles.author: Lotanna Emediegwu
articles.summary: Even in advanced economies such as the UK, hotter summers mean droughts in Africa and hurricanes in the Caribbean are becoming more frequent due to climate change, which has a negative impact on the economy. In the UK it's hotter summers than in the past.

articles.title: Louisiana's Coastal Restoration Movement Is Growing from the Ground Up
articles.author: Samantha Hindman
articles.summary: Louisiana is disappearing. More than 1,800 square miles of wetlands have vanished since the 1930's. Every 100 minutes, another football field of land slips into open water. The tide is pushing back communities and the region's ecosystems are collapsing. This content is for paid subscribers only.

articles.title: La Niña is likely to start soon. Here's what it means for Texas.
articles.author: Anthony Franze
articles.summary: NOAA has issued a La Niña watch for October and November. It's when sea-surface temperatures over the eastern Pacific Ocean, near the equator, are colder than average. This can affect the weather in Texas because of the influence of the polar jet stream over the northern Pacific Ocean. Since 1950, Austin has experienced above-average wintertime temps during 70% of LaNiña winters.

articles.title: Beachfront homes collapse into the sea as hurricanes batter US coast
articles.author: Holly Bishop
articles.summary: Beachfront homes in North Carolina have collapsed into the sea as two hurricanes sweep across the Atlantic. The houses were unoccupied and no injuries were reported. The area is littered with debris and high seas and large waves are expected to continue into the week, with further collapses possible.

articles.title: Dare County Public Works announces trash collection advisory due to inclement weather
articles.author: Staff Reporter
articles.summary: There will be no commercial trash collection in the villages on Hatteras Island today, October 1, 2025, due to inclement weather from Hurricane Humberto. Commercial trash collection will resume on Friday if conditions improve. If conditions become dangerous for sanitation truck drivers due to roadway weather impacts, trash collection won't occur.

articles.title: Red flags continue flying on Emerald Isle beaches over Imelda's impacts
articles.author: WITN Web Team

No injuries were reported, but further house collapses are possible. 35 structures decertified for occupancy since August due to erosion damage as sea levels rise.

articles.title: God aside, all is not right with the world

articles.summary: Al laments the impact humanity is having on the planet. Poet Robert Browning's Pippa's Song evokes a perfect natural world. He describes a 'dew-pearled hillside, a lark, a snail and a snail, and concludes that 'God's in His heaven, and it's all right with the world!' Al points out that our 'perfect natural world' has been under assault from varied human pressures for some decades now.

articles.title: October temperatures set to stay high, PMD says
articles.author: Attia Naveed
articles.summary: Temperatures will remain above normal throughout October. The department also cautioned that the warm weather will encourage the growth of dengue larvae, raising health concerns. River flows are predicted to decrease, reducing water availability for agricultural use.

The retreat and loss of glaciers is having an impact on Switzerland's landscape.

articles.author: China.dot.org
articles.summary: Astronomers in Australia have found the early Universe was warm before stars formed. Researchers were looking for the elusive "Epoch of Reionization" period 800 million years after the Big Bang, when gas heated up between galaxies and created stars. The study was published recently.

articles.title: Odisha on High Alert as Depression Intensifies: Heavy Rainfall Expected

Fishermen have received advisories against sea voyages and heavy rain warnings have been issued for several districts.

articles.title: Alpine glaciers are melting even on the highest peaks

articles.summary: Swiss glaciers have lost a quarter of their volume over the past decade. In 2025 their volume shrank by 3% compared to the previous year. Climate change is giving Swiss glaciers no respite. Almost all glaciers in the Alps could disappear by the end of the century.

articles.title: Coastal flooding and hazardous surf to peak Wednesday afternoon as Humberto and Imelda impact Outer Banks
articles.summary: Hurricanes Humberto and Imelda have created long-period swells on the Outer Banks. Coastal flooding and hazardous ocean conditions are expected to peak on Wednesday afternoon and continue through Thursday. N.C. Highway 12 on Hatteras Island remains open and passable after Wednesday's 2:30 a.m. high tide, but it's closed on northern Ocracoke Island. Five unoccupied homes collapsed in Buxton on Tuesday afternoon, and the beach is closed due to piles of dangerous debris.

articles.title: Moose Lodge hosts Monday dance
articles.author: Heather Shelton
articles.summary: Friends of the Arcata Marsh will sponsor a free tour of the marsh on Saturday. The Redwood Region Audubon Society will present a free guided field trip at the marsh. The Humboldt Handweavers and Spinners Guild will present 'Making My Way from Felt to Form' with Kristy Kun on October 9 at 6:45 p.m. at the Wharfinger Building, No. 1 Marina Way, Eureka. A dance party featuring live music takes place Mondays from 7 to 9:30 pm at the Moose Lodge, 4328 Campton Road, in Arcata.

articles.title: September was hottest on record in Japan's Okinawa: weather agency

Japan's average summer temperature was 2.36C above "the standard value", making it the hottest since records began in 1898. More than 100,000 people were taken to hospitals this summer with heatstroke.

articles.title: Refreeze the Arctic? Scientists split over polar geoengineering.
articles.author: Chelsea Harvey
articles.summary: As the Arctic warms, scientists are debating whether technological interventions are necessary or foolhardy. A recent paper suggests that polar geoengineering could cost billions of dollars, risk serious environmental damage and lure world leaders away from their carbon-cutting commitments. However, some scientists say technological cooling interventions may be needed to safeguard the world's fastest warming region.

articles.title: Swiss glaciers have shrunk by a quarter since 2015, study says
articles.author: Bias Comparison
articles.summary: Glaciers in Switzerland have lost a quarter of their volume in the past decade due to climate change. If carbon dioxide emissions are brought to zero within 30 years, about one-third of Swiss glaciers could still be saved, according to GLAMOS chief Matthias Huss.

articles.title: Swiss glaciers shrank 3% this year, the fourth-biggest retreat on record, experts say
articles.author: Jamey Keaten
articles.summary: Switzerland's glaciers have seen a 3% drop in total volume this year. This is the fourth-largest annual drop on record, due to the effects of global warming. The ice mass in Switzerland has declined by one-quarter over the last decade. Switzerland is home to the most glaciers in Europe.

articles.title: Swiss glaciers shrank 3% this year, the fourth-biggest retreat on record
articles.summary: Switzerland's glaciers have seen a 3% drop in total volume this year. This is the fourth-largest annual drop on record, due to the effects of global warming. The ice mass in Switzerland has declined by one-quarter over the last decade. Switzerland has the most glaciers in Europe.

articles.title: Swiss glaciers shrank 3% this year, the fourth-biggest retreat on record, experts say
articles.author: Jamey Keaten
articles.summary: Glaciers in Switzerland have faced 'enormous' melting this year with a 3% drop in total volume. This is the fourth-largest annual drop on record due to the effects of global warming. Ice mass in Switzerland has declined by one-quarter over the last decade. More than 1,000 small glaciers have already disappeared in Switzerland.

articles.title: Swiss glaciers shrank 3% this year, the fourth-biggest retreat on record, experts say
articles.summary: Switzerland's glaciers have shrunk by 3% this year due to global warming. The shrinkage is the fourth-largest annual drop on record. More than 1,000 small glaciers in Switzerland have already disappeared. The retreat and loss of glaciers is also having an impact on Switzerland's landscape, causing mountains to shift and ground to become unstable. Ukraine's president and U.N. nuclear agency head are sounding the alarm about increased safety risks at the Russia-occupied Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant.

articles.title: Are Atlantic Cod Stocks Declining Or Increasing?
articles.author: Principia Scientific
articles.summary: So will 'climate change' help or hurt the planet?   Â.      i.e. will it have any effect on the environment? Â   It's very difficult to say, but it's possible.

articles.title: Permafrost: the silent threat beneath our feet
articles.summary: Permafrost melt is one of the consequences of global warming. Many of the world's buildings and roads are built on permafrost. It takes several years for it to melt, but when it does, it can cause considerable damage to structures resting on it.

articles.title: ‘Deeply concerned': Officials fear for Australians in Gaza flotilla swarmed by drones
articles.author: David Crowe
articles.summary: Six Australians are on board some of the 50 civilian ships from 44 nations trying to land on the Gaza shore in defiance of Israeli controls on humanitarian aid for the war-torn zone. Activists on board the flotilla have reported being intercepted by Israeli ships as they approach the Gaza coast on Wednesday night, AEST.

articles.title: ‘Deeply concerned': Officials fear for Australians in Gaza flotilla swarmed by drones
articles.author: David Crowe
articles.summary: Six Australians are on board some of the 50 civilian ships from 44 nations trying to land on the Gaza shore in defiance of Israeli controls on humanitarian aid for the war-torn zone. Activists on board the flotilla have reported being intercepted by Israeli ships as they approach the Gaza coast on Wednesday night, AEST.

articles.title: ‘Deeply concerned': Officials fear for Australians in Gaza flotilla swarmed by drones
articles.author: David Crowe
articles.summary: Six Australians are on board some of the 50 civilian ships from 44 nations trying to land on the Gaza shore in defiance of Israeli controls on humanitarian aid for the war-torn zone. Activists on board the flotilla have reported being intercepted by Israeli ships as they approach the Gaza coast on Wednesday night, AEST.

articles.title: ‘Deeply concerned': Officials fear for Australians in Gaza flotilla swarmed by drones
articles.author: David Crowe
articles.summary: Six Australians are on board some of the 50 civilian ships from 44 nations trying to land on the Gaza shore. The flotilla has been intercepted by Israeli ships and could be near the shoreline on Wednesday night, AEST. Australia wants Israel to allow more humanitarian aid into Gaza.

articles.title: Maroubra Beach fire: Flames erupt over Sydney
articles.author: NICHOLAS COMINO
articles.summary: A large fire has engulfed part of Sydney's south, sending huge plumes of smoke over the suburb of Maroubra. Several blazes broke out on Wednesday evening in the south of the trendy suburb. There seems to be several fires close to the beach on the south end.

articles.title: Four Decades of Shoreline Changes in Southwestern Nigeria
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: Researchers have done a geospatial analysis of shoreline changes along the Southwestern coast of Nigeria. Their findings have implications for ecological stability, local communities, and urban planning. Urban expansion and infrastructural development have played a significant role in exacerbating shoreline erosion.

articles.title: Flotilla carrying Australians approaches Gaza
articles.summary: Flotilla carrying Australians approaches Gaza. The feature is currently unavailable, but we're working to restore it. Please try again later and don't be afraid to use the "Dismiss" button instead.    .   -

articles.title: Somalia: The German Embassy Launches Mogadishu Climate Talk On Peace and Security
articles.summary: Somalia is one of the countries most affected by climate change, despite contributing almost nothing to global greenhouse gas emissions. The first Climate Talk in Mogadishu was organised by the Embassy of Germany and the Berghof Foundation. It was a signal of long-term partnership between Germany and Somalia.

articles.title: September was hottest on record in Okinawa, weather agency says
articles.author: AFP-JIJI
articles.summary: Okinawa Prefecture experienced its hottest September on record. The entire country experienced its warmest summer since records began in 1898. More than 100,000 people were taken to hospital with heatstroke this summer for the first time in Japan's history. The temperature in Okinawa Prefecture in September was the highest since statistics began in 1946.

articles.title: Swiss glaciers melted sharply after light snowfall and heatwave, scientists say
articles.author: The Star
articles.summary: Switzerland's glaciers have seen their fourth-largest reduction in ice volume on record in the past 12 months, according to GLAMOS monitoring body. The glacier melt has been taking place in the area of Oberomans, Switzerland, where glaciers are located.

articles.title: NOAA cuts threaten Florida's hurricane defenses and recovery efforts
articles.author: John Paul "J.P" Brooker
articles.summary: President's proposed 2026 budget includes a $1.7 billion cut to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). This could negatively impact the accuracy of hurricane forecasting, which has improved by 50% over the last 20 years. Funding for several Florida-based programs, including research reserves and marine studies institutes would be eliminated.

articles.title: Switzerland's glaciers shrink by a quarter in just a decade
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Glaciers across the Alps have been retreating for more than a century, but in recent decades, the process has sped up as the climate warms. Since the early 1970s, more than 1,100 Swiss glaciers have disappeared completely. Switzerland's glaciers shed 24 percent of their volume between 2015 and 2025.

articles.title: September was hottest on record in Japan's Okinawa
articles.summary: The temperature in Okinawa in September was the highest since statistics began in 1946. Japan's average summer temperature was 2.36 degrees C above 'the standard value', making it the hottest since records began in 1898. More than 100,000 people were taken to hospitals this summer with heatstroke.

articles.title: World bank backs flood resilience project in Việt Nam
articles.author: Vietnam News
articles.summary: A recently approved World Bank plan aims to improve access to two of Việt Nam's vulnerable yet economically important regions. More than 1.2 million people are set to move to the coastal hub of Đà Nẵng and a highlands corridor of Gia Lai.

articles.title: Azerbaijan bets on control of water disasters' impact on farming revenues
articles.author: Alish Abdulla
articles.summary: Minister of Agriculture Majnun Mammadov spoke at the roundtable on "Climate-Resilient Agribusiness: Strategy, Investment and Policy Adaptation" held within the Baku Climate Action Week. He said the enhancement of climate resilience catalyzes a significant uptick in the agrarian welfare metrics.

articles.title: Weather Agency: September was Hottest on Record in Japan's Okinawa
articles.author: Asharq Al Awsat
articles.summary: The temperature in Okinawa in September was the highest since statistics began in 1946. The entire country experienced its warmest summer since records began in 1898. More than 100,000 people were taken to hospital with heatstroke this summer for the first time, according to the Fire and Disaster Management Agency.

articles.title: Climate change shrinks Swiss glaciers by a quarter in past decade: Report
articles.summary: Glaciers across the Alps have been retreating for more than a century, but in recent decades, the process has sped up as the climate warms. Between 2015 and 2025, the glaciers shed 24 percent of their volume, compared to 10 percent between 1990 and 2000. More than 1,100 Swiss glaciers have disappeared since the early 1970s.

articles.title: The Santa Claus effect: how expanding tourism ate into Lapland's green space
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: The number of visitors to Lapland has risen 160% in 30 years. There are concerns for the region's fragile ecosystem and indigenous practices. Europe is losing 600 football pitches of nature and crop land a day, according to the UNEP. Laplands was once a part of Europe.

articles.title: Trump says climate predictions were ‘wrong': How do climate models work, how accurate are they?
articles.author: Alind Chauhan
articles.summary: US President Donald Trump said that climate change is a 'con job' made by 'stupid people' at the UN General Assembly on September 23. Climate models are computer programs that help scientists understand how the climate changed in the past, how it is changing now and how it might change in the future. Modern climate models are fairly accurate when it comes to capturing large-scale patterns and long-term changes.

articles.title: Swiss glaciers melted sharply over past year: report
articles.author: Cecile Mantovani
articles.summary: A winter with little snow and heatwaves in the Swiss Alps caused the glaciers to lose 3% of their ice mass, according to GLAMOS and the Swiss Commission for Cryosphere Observation's report. .       .

articles.title: Swiss glaciers melted sharply over past year: report
articles.author: Cecile Mantovani
articles.summary: Switzerland's glaciers have experienced their fourth-largest reduction in ice volume on record in the past year.    GLAMOS monitoring body GLAMos reports this. The glaciers melted considerably over the past 12 months in Switzerland, which is a melting glacier nation.

articles.title: Major Cities See 25% Jump in Extreme Heat Days
articles.author: Emirates 24/7
articles.summary: There are 25 percent more extremely hot days each year in the world's biggest capital cities than in the 1990s, according to IIED analysis. In 2024, the International Institute For Environment and Development will examine extreme heat levels in world's 20 most populous capital cities.

articles.title: Gujarat coastline shrinks: 765 km eroded, salinity puts farmland at risk
articles.author: Gujarat Samachar
articles.summary: Gujarat's coastline is under threat due to unchecked industrialisation, illegal mining, deforestation and rising soil salinity. The Centre issued new guidelines to curb the issue in May 2025. Corrective measures have already reduced salinity across 87,860 hectares in Saurashtra.

articles.title: Labor's 2035 emission target a cruel deception
articles.author: Peter Boyle
articles.summary: Labor's 2035 greenhouse gas emission reduction target of 62-70% below 2025 levels is inadequate. It does not take into account the huge amounts of emissions from the burning of exported fossil fuels. Australia is the world's third-largest fossil fuel exporter, after Russia and the United States. Australia exports so much coal that it is the second-largest exporter of carbon dioxide emissions. Labor's approval of 31 new and expanded fossil fuel projects since 2022 means real domestic greenhouse gas emissions will rise.

articles.title: September was hottest on record in Japan's Okinawa, weather agency says
articles.author: CGTN
articles.summary: The temperature in Okinawa in September was the highest since statistics began in 1946. The entire country experienced its warmest ever summer.    The southern Okinawa region sweated through its hottest September on record, the country's weather agency said on Wednesday, after the entire country had a warmest summer.

articles.title: UN Climate Change Conference
articles.author: Enrico Biffis
articles.summary: Switzerland's glaciers have experienced their fourth-largest reduction in ice volume on record in the past year.    GLAMOS monitoring body GLAMos said on Wednesday that the glaciers melted considerably over the past 12 months and recorded their biggest loss of ice volume ever.

articles.title: Hurricane Recovery Farmers
articles.author: STW
articles.summary: Hurricane Recovery Farmers are picking cotton in Chris Hopkins' cotton field, Dec. 6, 2024, near Lyons, Georgia, as a result of Hurricane Sandy.    pic. taken from Mike Stewart's file.  Photo taken from AP Photo/Mike Stewart's File.

articles.title: Melting Candles of History: Switzerland's Glaciers in Retreat
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Switzerland's glaciers have experienced their fourth-largest decline in ice volume over the past year. A quarter of the country's glacier volume has vanished since 2015. The ongoing shrinkage of glaciers destabilizes mountain structures and heightens the risk of deadly avalanches. Experts emphasize the urgency of global carbon reduction strategies to preserve glacial formations.

articles.title: World's major cities hit by 25% more hot days than in 1990s
articles.author: Urdu Point
articles.summary: The world's biggest capital cities are now sweltering under 25 percent more extremely hot days each year than in the 1990s. Global temperatures are rising faster than governments expected and they don't seem to be reacting to the situation.

articles.title: Unlocking local government finance for climate resilience
articles.author: Gordon Noble
articles.summary: The National Climate Risk Assessment has drawn attention to the costs of climate-related events including extreme heat. The report projects that at +3.0°C of global warming, heat-related mortality is projected to increase by 444% in Sydney and 259% in Melbourne, with mortality and morbidity directly impacting labour productivity. Local governments are responsible for maintaining essential infrastructure such as roads, drainage systems, parks, libraries, and community facilities that are directly impacted by climate change. Local government is handcuffed in its ability to respond proactively to Australia's emerging climate risks.

articles.title: Major Cities See 25% Jump in Extreme Heat Days
articles.author: WAM
articles.summary: The number of days above 35C in 43 of the world's most populous capital cities rose from 1,062 a year from 1994-2003 to 1,335 from 2015-2024. The rise was seen across the world, with the average number of hot days doubling in Rome and Beijing and tripling in Manila. In Madrid, there are now 47 days a year over 35C compared with 25 before.

articles.title: COP29 president outlines Azerbaijan's climate agenda priorities
articles.author: Aytaj Shiraliyeva
articles.summary: Mukhtar Babayev is the COP29 President and Special Envoy of the Azerbaijani President for Climate Issues. He spoke at the Baku Climate Action Week (BCAW2025) organized by Azerbaijan. He stressed that the Caspian Sea can be an environmental disaster if not properly protected.

articles.title: How to keep growing profitable corn and forage crops despite fall armyworm
articles.author: Judith Maizey
articles.summary: Growers in the North Burnett are advised to plan ahead if they want to limit crop damage. Fall armyworm attacks are a regular occurrence in the area.    in the north Burnett. The weather is expected to get warmer soon. The fall armyworm is a serious problem.

articles.title: Road user charge may discourage EV take-up
articles.summary: Treasurers are working on a replacement to the fuel excise, but there's no timeline on when a change will be made. Australia's climate chief warns a road user charge could discourage drivers from switching to an electric vehicle, as it could be too expensive.

articles.title: Cork man reacts to theft of iconic letterbox – ‘it was part of the tapestry of rural Ireland'
articles.author: Irish Independent
articles.summary: Macroom man Tom Murphy warns rural communities to be aware of the dangers in rural communities.      Â  “Rural communities are at risk”, says Tom Murphy. He warns people not to take risks in rural areas.

articles.title: The Curse of The Blob
articles.summary: The Blob has returned to the Pacific Ocean from Japan to the US West Coast. The current version of The Blob established a sea surface temperature record in August 2025 of 20°C, a record for the ERSST data base going back to 1854. The Zeng study identified peak ocean temperatures exceeding normal by 3C and hitting levels that surpass what most marine organisms can survive. A US EPA study showed ocean heat content to 2,300 feet depth increasing 5-fold since 2020.

articles.title: Five more beachfront homes collapsed into the ocean after Hurricane Imelda generated rough surf in OBX
articles.author: Annette Weston
articles.summary: Hurricane Imelda created large waves and dangerous surf in the Outer Banks. Five seaside homes fell into the Atlantic Tuesday. NC12 on the north end of Ocracoke Island is closed until at least Thursday due to ocean overwash. The entire beachfront from northern Buxton through off-road vehicle ramp 43 is closed for public safety.

articles.title: Day 3 of Baku Climate Action Week 2025 kicks off
articles.author: Azernews
articles.summary: The third day of Baku Climate Action Week 2025 has officially started. Today's session will feature keynote speeches by COP29 President and the President's Special Representative on Climate Issues, Mukhtar Babayev, and Azerbaijan's Minister of Agriculture Majnun Mammadov. The agenda will focus on agriculture and food security in the context of climate change, climate technologies, and the sustainable management of regional water resources. Azerbaijan successfully hosted the first Baku climate action week in 2024 in partnership with London.

articles.title: Prairie Peril: Navigating Cuts in Water Research Funding
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The Prairie Farm Rehabilitation Administration has successfully advanced water research. Current funding uncertainties pose risks, especially as climate change exacerbates droughts and floods. Collaborative, applied research involving universities, advocacy organizations and non-profits is essential to diversify funding and fill gaps left by potential federal funding reductions.

articles.title: Over 4% of Irish coastal property now vulnerable to extreme weather events
articles.author: Kevin O'Sullivan
articles.summary: Vulnerability of buildings on the Irish coastline to flooding due to climate change has increased to 4.5% of all properties. Many of the at-risk properties have been built since 2020 and are concentrated in the Dublin region, which also has the highest number of potentially vulnerable new builds. Dublin alone would contain a third of potential claims (about €1.6 billion) post-2050. Co Clare is projected to see claims totalling almost €500 million post-1950.

articles.title: ‘Extreme coastal events' leave more than 100,000 Irish properties at risk, analysis shows
articles.author: Kevin O'Sullivan
articles.summary: There are 112,354 new addresses in Ireland at risk of flooding in an extreme coastal event. Dublin has the most newly-constructed buildings in an at-risk zone. Co Clare has 10% of the total potential claim volume. Co Louth is in the top three counties by potential claims volume.

articles.title: Climate Action Week in Azerbaijan's Baku enters its third day
articles.author: Aytaj Shiraliyeva
articles.summary: The third day of Baku Climate Action Week has kicked off in Azerbaijan's capital. The event will see speeches of COP29 President, Representative of the President of the Republic of Azerbaijan on Climate Issues Mukhtar Babayev, Azerbaijani Minister of Agriculture Majnun Mammadov and other officials.

articles.title: Cities swelter under record spring heat
articles.author: Andrew Hedgman
articles.summary: Brisbane is bracing for a scorching end to the week, with temperatures set to climb to 35C on Thursday. Queensland Fire Department extends a total fire ban across South East Queensland from Thursday until next Tuesday. Sydney reached 28C on Wednesday, while Canberra peaked at 25C. In northern regions, Darwin was sweltering at 34C by 2pm, while Broome baked at 32C under sunny skies. Victoria and Tasmania are contending with a cool southeasterly front that's bringing showers and gusty winds.

articles.title: Blistering heat and bushfire risk grip South East Queensland
articles.author: Andrew Hedgman
articles.summary: Brisbane is bracing for a scorching end to the week, with temperatures set to climb to 35C on Thursday. Queensland Fire Department extends a total fire ban across South East Queensland from Thursday until next Tuesday. Sydney reached 28C on Wednesday, while Canberra peaked at 25C. In northern regions, Darwin was sweltering at 34C by 2pm, while Broome baked at 32C under sunny skies. Victoria and Tasmania are contending with a cool southeasterly front that's bringing showers and gusty winds.

articles.title: Weather: Brisbane's 35C scorcher triggers total fire ban across SEQ
articles.author: Andrew Hedgman
articles.summary: Brisbane is bracing for a scorching end to the week, with temperatures set to climb to 35C on Thursday. The city could also wake to a smoke haze from fires burning across Queensland. The Queensland Fire Department has extended a total fire ban across South East Queensland from Thursday until next Tuesday. Sydney reached 28C on Wednesday, while Canberra peaked at 25C. In northern regions, Darwin was sweltering at 34C by 2pm, while Broome baked at 32C under sunny skies. Victoria and Tasmania are contending with a cool southeasterly front, bringing showers and gusty winds.

articles.title: Cordaid places roadmap for saline-resilient coastal farming
articles.author: Anniversary Issue-I
articles.summary: Cordaid has called for scaling up saline-resilient agriculture in Bangladesh's southern coastal belt, where rising salinity threatens food security and livelihoods. The COASTS project converted 5,000 hectares of land into farmland, trained 10,000 farmers, and introduced 15 salt-tolerant vegetable seed varieties.

articles.title: Antarctic sea ice hits its third-lowest winter peak on record
articles.author: The Standard 英文虎報
articles.summary: The world's largest iceberg, named A23a, is seen in Antarctica, January 14, 2024, in a picture obtained from social media. Rob Suisted took the picture.   http://naturespic.com/via REUTERS /File Photo

articles.title: Antarctic Winter Sea Ice Hits Third-Lowest Level In 47 Years
articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.summary: Antarctica's winter sea ice has hit its third-lowest peak in nearly half a century of satellite monitoring. This year's maximum reached 17.81 million square kilometers (6.88 million square miles) on September 17th. The 2025 maximum is the third lowest in the 47-year record, behind the all-time low in 2023 and the second lowest in 2024.

articles.title: Report: Burning of Fossil Fuel Poses Threat to 1.6bn People Globally
articles.author: Nigeria
articles.summary: Fossil fuel burning is damaging the world's climate and threatening the health of at least 1.6 billion people through the toxic pollutants it produces. About 900 million people are in the path of 'super-emitting' industrial facilities that deliver outsize doses of toxic air. Karachi, Guangzhou, Seoul and New York are among the cities badly affected.

articles.title: Australian Minister ‘Deeply Concerned' About Safety of Citizens on Gaza Flotilla
articles.author: Sydney Morning Herald
articles.summary: Six Australians are on board some of the 50 civilian ships from 44 nations trying to land on the Gaza shore in defiance of Israeli controls on humanitarian aid for the war-torn zone. Doctors say Palestinians are suffering malnutrition and civilian casualties in the Gaza war zone.

articles.title: Prolonged drought stunts the renowned wild blueberry crop in the Maritimes
articles.summary: This year's hot, dry weather and higher-than-average overnight temperatures reduced yields by 55 per cent to about 20 million pounds. Wild blueberry exports generated $121 million for Nova Scotia and contributed $81 million to New Brunswick's economy. Some of Nova Scotia's 175 wild blueberry farmers are considering selling land and seeking financial compensation from the province's Liberal government.

articles.title: Birds in July 2024 compared to August 2025
articles.summary: There has been a dramatic increase in bird numbers in the Marshall Islands since rats were eradicated from the nesting sites of the islands, which has led to an increase in the number of birds there. The eradication of rats was due to the presence of them on nesting sites.

articles.title: Australia Institute Launches New Documentary - Save Tuvalu, Save World
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Save Tuvalu, Save The World is a documentary about climate change in the Pacific island nation of Tuvalus. The documentary has already been shown in Australia three times. The young climate campaigner Gitty Yee visited Australia last week for three sold-out preview screenings of the documentary.

articles.title: October Will Be Wetter Than Normal in Costa Rica: National Meteorological Institute Predicts Late End of Rainy Season ⋆ The Costa Rica News
articles.author: Tcrn Staff
articles.summary: October is going to be a wetter-than-normal month in much of Costa Rica. The Pacific coast, the Central Valley, Guatuso, Los Chiles, and Upala could see up to 15% more rainfall than average. The Caribbean will maintain a drier pattern with a deficit close to 10%. The IMN will not publish the approximate dates for the end of the rainy season until mid-October.

articles.title: Scientists discover stunning cause of massive ice craters: 'Specific conditions in the area'
articles.author: Robert Crow
articles.summary: Giant gas emission craters were spotted in Siberia's remote Yamal and Gydan peninsulas since 2012. Scientists believe the formation of these craters is linked to the specific conditions in the area, such as abundant natural gas generation and seepage, and the limited thickness of the continuous permafrost. Permafrost thawing is a concern because it is tied to human-caused pollution.

articles.title: World Bank Backs Flood Reduction in Saint Lucia
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The World Bank's Board of Executive Directors has approved a new project to reduce flood risk in Saint Lucia's most vulnerable communities. The 25 M Saint Lucia Urban Resilient Flood Investment Project is expected to benefit almost 67,000 Saint Lucians. The project will focus on Castries, Anse La Raye and their river basins. It will also improve the government's capacity to manage climate impacts.

articles.title: News Corp embraces fantasy genre by turning climate crisis into ‘laughable' science fiction
articles.author: Graham Readfearn
articles.summary: The National Climate Risk Assessment, released this month, found climate change would affect all aspects of Australian lives and the country's economy. The Daily Telegraph ran a front page story with the headline 'SCIENCE FICTION: Doomsday report out of this world: US expert' based on Roger Pielke Jr's views. Pielk Jr is a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative thinktank with a record of opposing climate action. Monash University's Dr Andrew Watkins, a lead author of the risk assessment, and Christian Jakob, a climate modelling expert, say his focus on scenarios was not relevant.

articles.title: 5 more Outer Banks houses collapse into the ocean amid stormy seas
articles.author: The Washington Post
articles.summary: 17 homes have fallen along the Cape Hatteras National Seashore in the last five years, including 17 homes along the coast in the past five years alone.      Â   y   in the area of the national seashore.

articles.title: Warming oceans drive Antarctica's winter sea ice to near record low
articles.summary: Antarctica's winter sea ice has hit its third-lowest peak in nearly half a century of satellite monitoring. The sea ice acts as a stabilizing buffer, protecting the Antarctic Ice Sheet from entering the ocean and amplifying sea level rise. When the climate stays warmer, the ice sheet shrinks.

articles.title: Scaling up Energy Transition in East Asia and Pacific (World Bank Group)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: East Asia and Pacific region accounts for over a third of global greenhouse gas emissions. To continue growing and reducing poverty, the region needs to reduce fossil fuel use and greenhouse gas emission to grow and reduce poverty, says the UNFCCC. (http://www.unfccc.org/en/news/environment/environmental-related-issues/greenhouse-gas-emissions-in-east-asia-and-pacific-regions-increase-fossil-fuel-use, etc.

articles.title: Italy's Meloni says Gaza flotilla risks escalation, could ‘blow up' potential ceasefire deal
articles.author: Fox News
articles.summary: The Gaza-bound flotilla involving anti-Israel activists and celebrities, including Greta Thunberg, has drawn sharp criticism from the Israeli government and the public. It is expected to sail to Gaza on a pro-Palestinian ship. It will be led by an anti-Gaza activist.

articles.title: 5 homes collapse into the Outer Banks surf as Atlantic hurricanes swirl far offshore
articles.summary: Unoccupied houses along North Carolina's Outer Banks collapsed into the ocean Tuesday as Hurricanes Humberto and Imelda rumbled in the Atlantic. The homes were once propped on high stilts, but they fell due to sea levels rising due to global warming.

articles.title: 6 homes collapse into the Outer Banks surf as Atlantic hurricanes swirl far offshore
articles.summary: Six unoccupied houses along North Carolina's Outer Banks have collapsed into the ocean as Hurricanes Humberto and Imelda rumble in the Atlantic. Five of the houses collapsed Tuesday afternoon in Buxton and a sixth one overnight, the National Park Service says.

articles.title: 6 homes collapse into the Outer Banks surf as Atlantic hurricanes swirl far offshore
articles.author: GARY D. ROBERTSON
articles.summary: Six unoccupied houses along North Carolina's Outer Banks have collapsed into the ocean as Hurricanes Humberto and Imelda rumble in the Atlantic. No injuries have been reported. Ocean overwash prompted the state Transportation Department to close a portion of North Carolina Highway 12 on Ocracoke Island.

articles.title: Ecowatch: Are we still gulping down oil?
articles.summary: Global carbon emissions from energy grew in 2024 despite all the measures countries are taking to mitigate climate change. We should all keep a close eye on the numbers on energy use and keep an eye on them every year.    i.e. check the statistics on carbon emissions.

articles.title: Atlantic City warns of dangerous rip currents and surf due to hurricanes
articles.author: Atlantic City
articles.summary: Hurricanes Imelda and humberto are causing dangerous surf conditions and rip currents. Atlantic City beaches will be closed until further notice due to the weather conditions caused by the hurricanes.   Â   imelda.humberto is a Category 4 hurricane.

articles.title: Agribank warns farmers to prepare for rainy season risks
articles.author: Namibian Sun
articles.summary: Agribank warns farmers to prepare for rainy season risks. Farmers urged to adopt sustainable rangeland management practices. Climate change is making Namibia's rainy seasons increasingly unpredictable, with major implications for livestock farmers across the country, Agribank has warned.

articles.title: Japan logs 3rd-hottest September on record
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Japan's average temperature in September was 2.49 degrees Celsius higher than the mean temperature for 30 years from 1991 to 2020. The hottest September was logged in 2023, followed by 2024. Eastern and western Japan both saw temperatures higher than average by 2.7 degrees, and northern Japan 2.2 degrees. The higher-than-usual temperatures are expected to continue through the following month.

articles.title: ‘Listen to the cry of the Earth': Pope Leo takes aim at climate change sceptics
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Pontiff laments that some ridicule those who speak of global warming. This comes after Trump's claims of 'con job' on global warming being dismissed as a hoax by the media.   Â      in response to Trump's claim.

articles.title: Australia PM concerned about China's reported pause on BHP iron ore purchases
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Anthony Albanese is concerned about a report that China's state iron ore is unsafe.       in question.  The Australian Prime Minister said on Wednesday he was concerned about the report that the iron ore comes from China's iron ore mines.

articles.title: Pakistan's Deluge: Floods Threaten to Ignite Inflation and Cripple Food Supply Chains Anew
articles.author: The Call
articles.summary: Pakistan is once again grappling with the devastating aftermath of recent floods in 2025. The latest deluges are projected to exacerbate already fragile food supply chains and fuel a fresh wave.       in Punjab and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa.

articles.title: Climate change shrinks Swiss glaciers by a quarter in past decade: Report
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: Switzerland's glaciers have lost a quarter of their volume in the past decade alone, according to a study. The study heightens concerns over accelerating melting of the glaciers. The glaciers are disproportionately impacted by climate change and are losing ice at an accelerating rate.

articles.title: Greta Thunberg says people aboard Global Sumud Flotilla aren't ‘terrorists' after Israel launches smear campaign
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: Swedish environmental activist Greta Thunberg is sailing to Gaza as part of the Global Sumud Flotilla. She is calling out Israel for launching a smear campaign against the flotilla and linking it to Hamas. Israel thinks they can get away with only recycling their old arguments to lay the groundwork for violence against them.

articles.title: Ticks, asthma, cyanobacteria: How climate change is making us sick: Irwin
articles.author: Seacoast Online
articles.summary: Climate change is harming our health. New Hampshire is facing a growing incidence of new ticks and infections, and it's facing a dramatically increase in the number of ticks.    .   i   in this context, the health threat posed by ticks and Lyme Disease is getting worse.

articles.title: Ocean heat was off the charts, and Australia bore the brunt
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Oceans in Australia have been hotter than ever before in the past year. The impacts are being felt far away from the coast, as far away as you can get from the coasts as far as you could get.       .

articles.title: One third of children malnourished in Kenya's second-largest region as aid cuts drive food crisis
articles.author: AOL
articles.summary: One third of children in Turkana region of northwestern Kenya are malnourished. Aid cuts and climate-driven environmental impacts are to blame. Turkana is Kenya's second-largest county and has one million people. The Independent was shocked to see so many children and pregnant and breastfeeding women suffering from hunger and malnutrition.

articles.title: September Was Hottest On Record In Japan's Okinawa: Weather Agency
articles.author: MENA FN
articles.summary: Japan's southern Okinawa region had its hottest September on record, the weather agency said on Wednesday. The entire country experienced its warmest September ever, according to the agency's report. The whole country experienced the hottest September ever in September, it said.
